description: From Middle French. Compare French consistance.

entries.meaning: (archaic) The physical quality which is given by the degree of firmness, solidity, density, and viscosity; consistency.
The staying together, or remaining in close relation, of non-physical things.
examples: Her performance has lacked consistence over the last year.
This composer's musical work is of extraordinary consistence.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Standing still; quiescence; state of rest.
(obsolete) The condition of standing or adhering together, or being fixed in union, as the parts of a body; existence; firmness; coherence; solidity.
examples: When it was brought to the school it discharged from its right nostril, a whitish, viscid, clotty matter, which, although of little consistence, strongly adhered to the sides of the nostril.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) That which stands together as a united whole; a combination.
